Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Understanding how land use alters ecosystem function and population dynamics of key pollinator species
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cotton is the world's most widely-grown and economically important non-food crop, with a yearly harvest worth nearly $25 billion in the United States. Before cotton?s fluffy heads ("bolls") emerge, the plant produces large white flowers that attract insects, which visit the flowers to collect food (nectar and pollen) and to act as pollinators, moving pollen between flowers. While cotton plants can produce marketable bolls without the help of pollinating insects, pollinators greatly increase the size of bolls, with larger bolls producing greater yields and higher profits for growers. However, as human activities transform cotton-growing landscapes, there is concern that cotton fields are becoming are inhospitable to pollinators, preventing them from moving between fields in search of food and sites to reproduce. If this is happening, pollinators may disappear along with their valuable pollination services. The first steps in conserving cotton pollinators and the services they provide are to identify which insects are the best pollinators, and which human activities may be preventing them from persisting in rapidly-changing landscapes. This project will accomplish these first steps.

Using the tools of landscape genetics and ecology, this research looks for ways to restore and maintain pollinators in agricultural landscapes. Through behavioral observation, single visit pollen deposition, pollen load analysis, and the estimation of visitation frequency, researchers will determine the efficacy of all cotton pollinators. They will then use next generation genetic sequencing techniques to determine the population dynamics of the three most effective pollinator species as a function of landscape composition. The goal is to identify specific landscape barriers that may hamper pollinator dispersal and colonization. This research will develop genomic resources to investigate pollinator dispersal, migration, and colonization, which will in turn offer an opportunity to increase crop yields and profits while also benefiting the environment. Additionally, the project will provide research experience and mentoring for an early-career ecologist.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pollinators, and the pollination service they provide, can increase yield in many of the agricultural crops on which we depend. Cotton, which makes larger fruits when pollinated by insects, tends to grow in and around highly developed urban and agricultural landscapes. What is not well established is how highly developed urban and agricultural areas affect the services provided by these important insect communities.

Our project had two main goals. First, we investigated the contribution of different insect pollinator species to overall pollination service provided for conventional cotton plants in South Texas. Second, we examined the genetic consequences of land use change on these important insect species.

For our first goal, we examined aspects of pollinator foraging behavior, suitability of pollen grains carried and deposited by pollinators, and the abundance of each of the 97 pollinator species that visited cotton flowers over a three-year period. With this information we were able to rank the quantity and quality of pollination services provided by each pollinator species in the region. We found that only about half of the visits made by potential pollinators were to flowers that were likely to set fruit, that many species visited when flowers were not actually receptive to pollination, and that many species either carried very little cotton pollen or large amounts of non-cotton pollen. As such, many of the potential pollinators that we observed were actually unlikely to be helpful in the setting of cotton fruits.

 

For our second goal, we examined genetic patterns of three common pollinator species in our study region. Specifically, we selected three focal pollinator species, Bombus pensylvanicus, Melissodes tepaneca, and Lasioglossum bardum. These species vary in size, are native to our region, and are all common throughout much of North America. Specimens were collected and stored using a few common, widely used techniques. Before we could analyze the genetic patterns of our different species, we first had to see if the various collection and storage techniques we used affected the quality of extracted DNA. We found that those insects stored in 100% ethanol yielded the best results, and as a consequence, we focused our analysis on the single insect species that was collected into 100% ethanol: the native, solitary, ground nesting bee, Melissodes tepaneca. With the DNA extracted from our 384 M. tepaneca specimens, we are currently working on genome assembly, landscape characterization, and model testing to compare three models in which land cover type varies in its suitability to bee movement.

 

Finally, as an additional research objective, we used a comparative study to investigate the role of landscape context in shaping pollinator community composition at a global scale. For our expanded project goals, we show that the factors impacting bee communities in cotton agroecosystems are the same in Brazil and the U.S.: bee abundance increases with contemporary abundance of semi-natural habitat, the density of the cotton bloom, and decreases with the loss of semi-natural habitat over a five-year period.

 

Our project advanced scientific literacy in South Texas, one of the most underserved, socio-economically, and ethnically heterogeneous U.S. regions (56% Hispanic, 7% African American, 2% Asian American). We developed outreach materials for Texas State Parks, Texas A&M Extension Centers, and private land owners, and demonstrated our commitment to scientific literacy by participating in extension events through Texas A&M, Corpus Christi (a Hispanic Serving Institution), and enhanced scientific literacy in early education, by presenting at educational camps at the Welder Wildlife Refuge in Sinton, Texas.  Our findings have resulted in three peer reviewed journal articles, with another two in preparation and has provided researchers and land managers with empirical results upon which to model conservation and restoration efforts in our region.
